title: 111_hr2991
content:
The Act titled "Department of Transportation Bonding Assistance Authority Act of 2009" allows the Secretary to guarantee surety against loss from a principal's breach of bond. The Act allows the Secretary to guarantee surety against loss resulting from a breach of bid, payment, or performance bonds by an eligible small business concern bidding on a contract. The Secretary may guarantee a surety against loss if a person needs a bond to bid on a contract, cannot obtain it without a guarantee, and is expected to fulfill the contract terms. The Secretary can also indemnify the surety for losses incurred due to the guarantee. The Secretary may agree to indemnify a surety against losses in avoiding a breach of a bond guaranteed by the Secretary. The payment by the Secretary shall not exceed 10 percent of the contract price unless deemed necessary and reasonable. The Secretary may reimburse a surety for losses incurred in avoiding a breach of a guaranteed bond, with payment not exceeding 90 percent of the surety's loss. The Secretary shall not make duplicate payments and the reimbursement amount is subject to certain conditions. The Secretary may reimburse a surety for losses incurred in avoiding a breach of a guaranteed bond, with payment not exceeding 90 percent of the surety's loss. The Secretary shall reimburse the surety, except in cases of fraud, breach of terms, or violation of regulations. The Secretary may establish regulations for participating sureties. The Secretary may establish regulations for participating sureties, requiring them to meet standards for underwriting, claim practices, and loss ratios. The Secretary may also adopt a procedure for reimbursing sureties for paid losses, with subsequent adjustments. Participating sureties must make reports to the Secretary and allow audits by the Secretary. The Secretary may audit participating sureties' documents and records as required. Sureties must be audited at least once every three years. The Secretary will administer the program and establish fees for small businesses and premiums for sureties. Additionally, there is a provision for a State program. The Secretary will establish a program for selected States to carry out activities related to issuing guarantees and assisting small business concerns with the help of sureties. States participating in the program will be subject to assessments and standards set by the Secretary. The Secretary will establish a program for selected States to issue guarantees and assist small business concerns through sureties. States in the program must meet prescribed standards and submit annual reports to the Secretary. Additionally, the Secretary will provide annual reports to relevant committees on the implementation of the program and the number of sureties involved. The Senate report outlines the implementation of a program for States to issue guarantees to small businesses through sureties. It includes details on the number of sureties, States involved, small businesses participating, guarantees paid, and States managing program amounts. Definitions for terms like "bid bond" are also provided. The curr_chunk provides definitions for terms like "bid bond" and "eligible small business concern," specifying criteria for small businesses to qualify under different categories. The curr_chunk defines terms related to small businesses, including those owned by service-disabled veterans, qualified HUBZone small businesses, and women-owned small businesses. It also defines the term "obligee" in the context of bid, payment, and performance bonds. The curr_chunk defines terms related to payment and performance bonds, including payment bond, performance bond, prime contractor, and principal. The curr_chunk defines terms related to contractors, principals, subcontractors, and the Secretary of Transportation. The curr_chunk defines terms related to subcontractors and sureties in contracts. The curr_chunk discusses the authorization of appropriations for the Secretary to carry out activities related to subcontractors and sureties in contracts. $50,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2010 to 2014, with a limit of $20,000,000 for activities under paragraph (8). SEC. 3. NATIONAL INFORMATION CLEARINGHOUSE.

Amends Section 332(b)(1) of title 49, United States Code to include "any Federal, State, or local mode of transportation".

SEC. 4. PROVISION OF RELEVANT INFORMATION.

Amends Section 332(d) of title 49, United States Code by striking specific entities.
